multiple_choice_question.text: What does this formula represent? Ψ = Φnlm(R) Ψ\' ?
choices: The probability density of finding a nucleon at a specific point in space.
The energy levels of a harmonic oscillator potential.
The factorization of a many-nucleon wave function into center-of-mass and relative motion components.
The nuclear shell model Hamiltonian.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the key assumption made in this formula for the alpha particle wave function? Ψα = Φnlm(R) Ψα = ΣΧ nl (n,0):lm η
choices: The alpha particle is a point-like particle.
The intrinsic state of the alpha particle has a (0s)4 configuration.
The alpha particle is unbound.
The alpha particle interacts weakly with other nucleons.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does this expression represent? 1/(4η Πί(πή!)αί Πίαΐ!)
choices: The normalization constant for a harmonic oscillator wave function.
The cluster coefficient used in the expansion of the alpha particle wave function.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does this table demonstrate about the effect of increasing Nmax on the alpha particle wave function? Table 1: Select configuration content of NCSM wave functions for 4 He.
choices: The (sd)4 configuration becomes dominant.
Configurations beyond (0s)4 gain significance.
The wave function becomes less spatially extended.
The binding energy of the alpha particle decreases.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main conclusion drawn from comparing the spectroscopic factors obtained using SU(3) and realistic alpha cluster wave functions? Table 2: Spectroscopic Factors for sd shell ground states using SU(3) and realistic a cluster wave functions.
choices: Both methods yield identical results.
Realistic wave functions underestimate spectroscopic factors.
SU(3) wave functions are more computationally efficient.
Realistic wave functions provide a more accurate description of clustering phenomena.
